reviewText:
So BEFORE I TALK ABOUT THIS GAME even though I did want to enjoy it, I need to point out some big problems about it:
- Firstly, SAVE OFTEN AND SAVE PLENTY because the game has a bizarre bug that sometimes stops you saving and it has no autosave feature, even though this is a game from 2009.
- Secondly, when you have to draw on a map and it tells you to draw an Ellipse, just try to do this exactly - https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/43253912/map-%2816-9%29.jpg - it is absurdly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t precise and I'm gonna save you a lot of hassle.
- Thirdly, if you cannot load up the game for some reason, go to the PhysX folder inside the game's Steam folder and click on PhysX drivers.  Then click repair" and it should work.  If not there is the Steam Community that gave me this advice.

Now
date: the actual review of the game.  The world's most famous fictional detective versus the most infamous serial killer by name have finally come to blows in a strange blend between fantasy and reality in this game
hoursPlayed: the story is very well-composed concerning the killer's trail.\nAs Sherlock and Watson
voteText: you must hunt down the murderous Whitechapel Killer following his deadly clues
helpfulPercent: reliving the famous incidents that granted Whitechapel a most deadly reputation for the next 130 years.  The voice acting could be better
votesHelpful: though I do enjoy Watson's VA greatly as well as the odd incidental NPC wandering around.\n\nThe anatomical gathering of clues and deductions are very fun and remain more or less the same throughout the series with a great precision.  Some of the puzzles are actually really neat
votesTotal: however there are some that are quite frankly badly conceived due to not being great puzzles.\nAnd I'm not saying that because I'm stupid
commentsCount: there is a puzzle in the game that requires you to know about a specific war.  That is really terrible
column16: and any puzzle that requires outside knowledge
column17: is a bad puzzle.  That's the only example
column18: but there are some other puzzles that are rather unclear as to what to do.\n\nThankfully
column19: this series has gotten a lot better and I do recommend more people to play the much later instalments
column20:
especially The Testaments of Sherlock Holmes which is MUCH more well-played than this game frankly.  So TL;DR

Pros:
- Excellent well-composed accuracy concerning the various details and theories of Jack the Ripper
- Anatomical deductions are pretty fun to do

Cons:
- The save bug which screwed me out of 6 hours of gameplay
- One or two puzzles are either outright unfair in requiring knowledge of certain things
column22: I want to give this game a Neutral rating as there's a lot to like but also a lot to dislike.  If you REALLY like Sherlock Holmes
column23: try to get it and see what happens.  But for the love of God

reviewText: Probably the most exciting Sherlock Holmes adventure ever made in video games.\nThough the visuals aren't perfect and some puzzles may not be as clear as they should be, the whole picture of the game seems more than satisfying, considering there's a bunch of surprising story twists to discover, and the ambience here is remarkable. Moreover, the gameplay itself also has a couple of aces up its sleeve to get one's attention during the playthrough.\nGear up and bring two legends together while leading your own investigation of the case that terrified London in 1888. I strongly recommend you to.

reviewText:
As a few other of the Sherlock series games this one just doesn't want to start properly. It freezes after the 'New Game' button is clicked and fails after you minimize it. Useless!

Update! I did find the solution:
Originally posted by swenor: Open Find and search for 'PhysXLoader64.dll' , it should be in your C:\...\Nvidia etc. folder. Copy the file and paste it in your game folder, where the .exe is. If you have a 64-bit version of windows, try pasting it in the C:\Program Files folder, since that is the 64-bit folder and the Nvidia folder is in C:\Program Files (x86). Have fun :)
voteText: 16 of 16 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Do you like classic Victorian era Sherlock Holmes?
Are you intrigued by the Whitechapel murders of 1888?
Then you will love this game!

Cleverly the game developers have meshed together these two iconic characters into one very plausible story. You play as Detective Sherlock Holmes and his companion Dr John Watson either in first or third person perspective (depending on taste) as you investigate the five canonical victims of Jack the Ripper.

While this game suffers from PS2/Xbox era graphics (It looked dated even at its time of release) it does however still manage to conjure up a very detailed, authentic, and atmospheric London of the period.

Puzzles can be frustrating at times especially those that do not directly impact the murder cases themselves but overlook this fault and there is plenty to enjoy here.

I would recommend this game and I give it a solid 8/10
voteText: 18 of 23 people (78%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Take literature's most famous detective, Sherlock Holmes, and make a crossover with the most feared serial killer of the Victorian London era, Jack the Ripper. Sounds awesome, right? Well, I think so since I'm a geek. For the most part, this was an enjoyable adventure game even with its flaws.

+ Seriously, I've always thought this crossover would've been a great idea, glad to see it actually happened.
+ The deduction boards were probably the best puzzles, at least in my opinion; they were fun and required some thinking.
+ 1st person view addition, I already prefer this over 3rd person view for adventure games.
+ Good story, provides some suspense and thrills through out.
+ Not too challenging, and not exactly easy either. Progressive difficulty is done right for the most part.
+ Analyzing victims is lots of fun lol.
+ Dat ending.

- Errands, bleh. I'm fine with that in GTA, Skyrim, etc. But here, not exactly the most fun time.
- Graphics are crap for a 2009 game.
- Every now and then, you'll find grammatical errors in the subtitles. It annoys me.
- Voice acting isn't exactly the greatest.
- Some puzzles are dumb; for example, why does Sherlock need a pivot" and a stick to move a barrel? Is he weak? lol.
- Some puzzles are annoying when it comes to registering your solution
date: such as the one where you narrow down Jack's "comfort zone" and the final deduction.\n\nIf you're a fan of Sherlock
recommended: or interested in Jack the Ripper case
voteText: if you love mysteries

reviewText:
I'd love to give this game a glowing review because it was great for me, but it is apparent from reading the forums that many people have issues running this game. For this reason, I'll supply my specs, though I cannot certify that this will make the game run for you:
Win 7 64 bit
Radeon HD 7770
AMD quad core 2.94 ghz

On with the game,

It's an adventure game with a few twists.
First off, you can operate the game from two different perspectives: Third-person for the old school point and click feel, and first person, which I prefer.
Besides the collecting items, you will have the opportunity to examine crime scenes and fill out some diagrams that include the clues you've gathered. The game won't let you fail these. Though at first thought that might seem lazy, the game is pretty much packed with detail and it's hard to see the devs making branching paths given the amount of attention and longevity of the game. Along the same lines the game also won't let you leave certain areas without collecting all the items.
There are many texts to read in this game and I would say that it is important to read them, as most do divulge important information that is pertinent to your case.

The voice acting, aside from one character who is thankfully absent for most of the game, is top notch. You can tell that, even though there was a budget as far as recording goes, the devs spared no expense for finding actors who wanted to portrey their roles well.
The music is fitting and includes some great pieces from the Romantic era including one of my personal favs, Schubert's Trio in Eb.

While the puzzles can be hit or miss, they mostly hit. They make sense and you should feel like you understand what the game wants from you, though there is one puzzle that involves a map that is somewhat obtuse given to a problem with widescreen resolutions, but it is do-able without much fussing about.

Though the graphics aren't the best by today's standards they do the job. The environments are well done and I felt very immersed in the places the game put me in. Hookers, drunks and theives around every corner.

All of these things came together for a perfect storm of presentation. Nothing felt out of place and I was enthralled with this title from beginning to end.

If you're looking for an adventure title that'll suck you in you should definitely give this title a go, though you should do your research to figure out if it'll run for you.

reviewText: This game surprised me, and got me into the Frogwares Sherlock Holmes games. I originally played it on Xbox 360 as a rental when it released, the Title caught my interest. Turned out to be a game I loved so much I bought it again on Steam. The PC version is far superior with the exception of the following, but don't let it sway you away, it can be corrected. It's not a broken game any means, just needs help on newer hardware when you first install. Some users (like myself) have an issue with the game mot loading initially: for most people this can be easily corrected by opening the game's folder (C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\SteamApps\common\Sherlock Holmes versus Jack the Ripper\Support\PhysX") and re-installing the two PhysX installers
date: and selecting the repair option if asked to by the installer for each one.\n\nNow.. about the game. This game has good performance and plays well on a rig that pumps 30 or 60+ FPS. The game looks great too. It may not blow you away graphically
recommended: but you can see the developers cared about quality. Little things - like tiny signs pasted to a brick wall are clear and easy to read

voteText: the lighting and shadows are nice and mood-setting: little things like this you will notice as you play. I like this game's style.\n\nThe game does have a few places where you can tell they were developing on a budget. Some of the NPC characters walking the streets are recycled

reviewText: I am playing and reviewing Frogware's Sherlock Holmes series in chronological order of the games. Even though this game is the fifth installment this game seems to precede The Awakened & Nemesis in terms of chronological narrative. This is seen in this installment we are introduced to Barnes the book store owner as if for the first time while he was a known character in the last two. Otherwise this game could be played by itself since this deals with the actual events of the Jack the Ripper case instead of many fictional characters in the series. This game was very well presented that checking up on some of the minor details I am surprised how well Frogware presented a plausible answer to the Jack the Ripper mystery.\n\nThe game isn't completely full of perfect creations. Some of the puzzles are so insanely hard with no real indication of feed back or clear instruction is just guess work. In addition to this, alot of the quests felt like one giant errand run tangent from one person for the next to get some basic clues. The ending ties the fictional resaults of Sherlock Holmes and the real life outcome of the case which was indeed very intresting. If a bit disapointing. Overall this game is good but not great. It definately calls back to the horrific acts done in The Awakened. The ending is more than enough to play though the game to see how it all ties together.

reviewText:
I joined Steam recently and this was one of the first games I purchased. I have since completed the game and I love the depicted Victorian era and British English.

Growing up reading Sherlock Holmes novels, his methods of deduction remains elusive to me. This game guides you to solving the mystery from a first-person perspective of Sherlock Holmes or Dr. Watson.

I have read reviews lamenting that the game play leans more towards running errands for NPCs. But I think it introduces the player to the NPCs. And running errands build up trust between them, hence the inclination to provide information that they otherwise would not tell the police.

In particular, the story is congruous with the alleged crimes by Jack the Ripper in Whitechapel. The ending is great and characteristic of Sherlock Holmes' eccentricity. All in all, the story unfolded at a pace that kept me tether to the screen. Good job, Frogwares!

reviewText:
WARNING NVIDIA USERS: The game might get stuck on the first loading screen the first time you start playing the game. If this happens, check the forum for fix. Worked for me.

Very good game for it's time and on level with the rest of the good part of this series.
The voice actors and music are the same as in previous games; decent to good, nothing terrible in voice acting but a few random volume/quality changed from sentence to sentence some times.

The story follows Sherlock Holmes as he investigates the brutal murders of some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in Whatechapel, London. The game is slightly less gory and bloody than other games in the series, mostly because the murder victms you inspect are drawings and dolls, and not 3d-models, which gives a completely different feel; but then again you may not want to see models of women with their guts and organs ripped out and face cut open, so a pretty good design choice. Still not a game safe for children.

The game visits both new places and a few places known from other game in the series. The puzzles still give no clues about how they are to be solved, which can be frustrating. There is no failure state in this game, so no real reason to save often (thought there is no autosave, so do save if you plan to closing the game), and the game never crashed for me.

The game does not rely as heavily on document-reading as the previous ones and there's no quiz or direct minor questions asked to chekc if you're paying attention. You may have to read up to solve a few of the puzzles though.

This is a pretty good adventure game with some major flaws.
First, the 3D engine is just hideous. The lighting looks awful and the characters cast no shadows - that looks really bad especially at night. I don't think that was acceptable even in 2009.

However the investigation is a lot of fun, dialogues are well written and the story overall is pretty interesting.

reviewText:
Sherlock Holmes may not be the best in Frogware's Sherlock Holmes series, but I definitely think it's the most interesting of the lot. Where most games in the series are based in fiction, Sherlock Holmes vs Jack the Ripper is based on actual history, and it sticks to it surprisingly well. Almost every character in the game was an actual person involved in the case, and the game follows a possible interpretation of the events (which, interestingly, actually goes against Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's own theory which speculated that the Ripper could actually be female) pretty closely. The Whitechapel regions are also recreated fairly well, though they do reuse a lot of obvious models from the previous games in order to fill the larger street population.

This does cause the potential issue of it not being interesting enough, however; the game is historically accurate enough that it does a pretty effective job of killing the mythological status that Jack has gained through most works of fiction about him, which may or may not disappoint fans of his story - this game is very much a story of the man, rather than the legend. The real-life inspiration also leads to the game being a bit less gorey than previous games like Sherlock Holmes: Awakened, with most of the corpses in this being replaced by slightly tamer drawings to give respect to the real victims - the final victim isn't even shown on screen except in a clay replica back at Holmes's office, due to the extent of damage that the real-life Ripper did to her.

Overall, while I can't say this game is my favorite in the series, it's still pretty great, and while its portrayal of the Ripper might not please everyone, I thought it was interesting to see the case from a historic perspective instead of being heavily fictionalized.

reviewText: After a string of mediocre or downright terrible adventure games, Frogwares inexplicably made one of the best I've ever seen. Sure, you still have some of the now cliched puzzles involving items or sliders, but the focus of the game is DETECTION, because Sherlock Holmes, they realized suddenly, is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed detective. So you put together timelines, draw on maps, organize suspects, steal evidence, go over pages and pages of documents -- it's great, and you really FEEL like you're solving a mystery, unlike most mystery adventure games where you're solving a 15 puzzle.\n\nBuy it.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Sherlock Holmes versus Jack the Ripper is a bit of a mixed bag. obviously the game centers around the legendary and and notorious slayings of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in whitechapel,london in 1888 and the famous fictional detective charater sherlock holmes. The game is from 2009 and its a point and click adventure that has its ups and downs. The graphics are ok and sets the atmosphere of victorian london well. The story is gripping as the true events and thats propably what kept me playing this game to the end. The game works pretty well at some points and has a level that is interesting to solve on other times the puzzles seem insanely difficult to solve. i have in the past back in the days (on amiga & mid 90'ies pc) played alot of adventure point and click games like monkey island, dark seed, phantasmagoria and so on. but this one has some practically unsolvable puzzles that in my opinion should have been dumbed down a bit, well its not that they are unsolvable but several 20 numerical codes will take an unreasonable time to solve atleast. well i i wasnt interested in spending hour upon hours on some of those codes so i honestly used a walktrough for some parts of the game and even then these codes was a hazzle to say the least. Besides from some of the puzzles and the mechanics i had problems with the game on different fronts as the game sometimes froze it wouldnt save on regular basis and i played it on a pc from the time of its release so i had to keep saving the game as often i would remember as i forgot it a couple of times and had to replay 2-3 hours of gameplay a couple of times. As i said it has its ups and downs but unless you are really interested in sherlock holmes or jack the ripper or for that sake point and click adventures i would not rcommend this game at all and im sure there's way better point and click adventures at the market. But i had some joy with it but wont rate it higher than 5.5-6/10

reviewText:
This game is the first one from that Humble Bundle I played. Too bad this game set the bar too high, and made the other Holmes games look less appealing. Especially the older games.
Having said that, the game is a fine game, and one which I hope Frogwares continues to build as a standard of quality.

Basically, you solve various crimes committed by Jack the Ripper. Each case brings you closer to the killer, to which his methods are ever so questionable. Still, Holmes does need to do his job, and solve this case.
Like from Holmes: Awakened" and "Holmes: Nemesis"

reviewText:
Despite what Steam says I have completed 3/4 of SHvJtR ... then SHvJtR crashed taking me back a long way. I tried again taking an hour to replay through all the puzzles I had already solved. Knowing that the game was probably going to crash again I tried to save repeatedly but it turns out the save-function fails past a certain point. SHvJtR crashed again at the same point (at Liz Stride's murder scene). I gave up.

Some other points:
- inspired by actual history: yay?
- The graphics are bad and look even worse with age.
- unskippable dialogue
- what are you supposed to do most of the time? No clear direction about what you can do.
- Voice Acting is OK
- puzzles are either OK or bad
- Combine the Hammer and Tongs together in your inventory because. You have this and many other stupid inventory puzzles that make almost no sense.
- many puzzles are find-the-missing-object-which-is-always-in-the-background-but-not-active-until-after-a-random-conversation-later

SHvJtR is not all bad, it's just that Frogware's latest Sherlock games are much better.  Save yourself the disappointment and buy a recent Sherlock Holmes game instead. I really enjoyed The Testament of Sherlock Holmes.

reviewText:
Truly a fun game. I'd reccomend it to any history or sherlock holmes  fans, or even anime fans of Black Butler.  I had the same issue getting the program to start as others have noted in their reviews. If you follow the advice given by several other people in their reviews, then the game will work perfectly!

I had quite a lot of trouble with many of the puzzles, and often needed help to get through them, though my least favorite was the map at the end to pinpoint the killer.

The plot, however, is quite enjoyable and very much worth the time and $10 to get it. I would love to collect the rest of the titles for Sherlock Holmes, and I feel each one makes me just a little smarter. The history of it was very well researched, especially the conditions and mutilations of the bodies and injuries they suffered from their murder. It took me about 15 hours to solve, including annoying puzzles. Still, totally worth it, and I look forward to playing it all over again.

reviewText:
I love the Frogwares game series based on Sherlock Holmes. I am a Sherlock Holmes fan, a Lovecraft fan and deeply interested in Ripper-lore as well, and if I didn't know better I'd think that Frogwares are going out of their way to please me.

The games are by no means perfect, and this one is no exception, but if you are as into the protagonist and subject matter as I am, you'll forgive the flaws.

The pros:
-The voice acting for the characters of Holmes and Watson are very close to how I have always imagined them from the stories
-The story is very well researched; the developers have obviously spent a lot of time collecting materials and connecting them with the story as it unfolds. This also means that, like the other Holmes games from Frogwares, there are lots of documents to read. That may be a plus or minus, based on your preference.
-It feels like you are actually solving the crime in a good whodunnit
-The conclusion is far from the worst take I have seen. And for the most part, I think the game treats the evidence astutely.
-The puzzles related to the murders (decuctions, conclusions etc.) are fun, if rather easy.

The cons:
-The game is very linear and holds your hand a lot of the time. When you need to check out a new location, Holmes will tell you precisely that, whether it was obvious or not. And you can't leave locations until your work there is done (No
recommended: nor can you go back to locations where your work is already done ("I have no reason to go that way"). It would make the game a lot more challenging - and immersive - if you were allowed to go wherever you pleased. That would make the game a lot harder
voteText: and the first play-through would certainly take a lot longer.\n-The puzzles in this game are for the most part arbitrary and irrelevant to the case (fix a gas leak
helpfulPercent: fixing an electric winch by connecting wires
votesHelpful: fishing out a necklace from between floorboards in a slide puzzle etc.)
votesTotal: though challenging and entertaining enough\n-Some puzzles are just... odd ("Oy vey
votesFunny: I would lend you my mask
commentsCount: but unfortunately it is in that cobra cage for some reason
column16: so you will have to figure out a way to get the snake out first"). Brings a bit of levity to the game
column17:
though.
-Tedious errands ("I will tell you what I know if you do such and such for me")
-The quality of the voice acting varies.

Still
column21: and if your interests are at all similar to mine I can definitely recommend it."

reviewText:
Very fun to play, interesting storyline etc etc. The case of Jack the Ripper is definitely one of my favorite mysteries in this world.

I recommend the game. It plays well in general, but there were some annoying things I faced during my gameplay:
it:
1) It was a bit bothersome to get the game to work at all. However, there's advice on how to do this in the game's forum.
2) Saving will occassionally malfunction. In this case I recommend you restart the game right away because the game is likely to crash sooner or later. At least that was the case for me. My advice is to save often to avoid losing lots of progress.
3) Ellipses should be wider than needed. You'll understand eventually what that means.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
The game feels something of a combination of  The Secret of the Silver Earring and The Awakened, with on one hand a dark subject matter and lots of realistic detective work, and on the other high reliance on the player's own ability to connect the right clues to draw the correct conclusions. Many of the suspects were actual people who have been suspected of the killings at one point or another. Unfortunately, the story only barely holds together, with lots of running back-and-forth and long-winded, badly acted dialogue.

Ultimately, the player needs to choose between half a dozen possible suspects. I couldn't even remember who one of them was, and another had already been cleared of suspicion. Apart from one the rest I had never even considered suspects, and the actual guilty party stuck out like a sore thumb. There had been more credible suspects earlier in the game, but these had been proven innocent, perhaps unwisely, as this made the conclusion of the game feel quite patronising.

Also patronising was how instead of more realistic depictions of the victims, the player has to make due with caricatures or even dolls -- even when Sherlock is examining the victims in person. One can't help but feel the game has been cleaned up for larger audiences -- The Awakened had featured significantly more gruesome imagery. Despite its flaws, the game is still worth a play, if only barely.

reviewText: Sherlock Holmes versus Jack the Ripper is a fun and creative game pitting the famous Baker street detective again the notorious whitechapel serial killer. In the game you control both Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson in a race against time to try to figure out who is the infamous Jack the ripper, the killer of whitechapel. A quite fun game, if you are willing to try your wits against a puzzle game instead of a shooter or adventure.

reviewText: I enjoy the deduction aspects of this game, but it gets really frustrating often due to bad controls and wonky cues. The controls for walking around are ridiculously clunky. Using items is a hassle as half the time you have to equip an item then click on something to use it, and the other half you can use the item automatically. Some times when you click an item or location, it doesn't even describe what the item is. The game is difficult, but often for the wrong reasons and it's frustrating. I've heard good things about the Sherlock series, and hopefully the other games aren't like this.

reviewText: Interesting game, but there's a lot of bugs. I just lost 2 hours of gameplay (I assumed autosave was a thing...) due to a major crash of the software. The mouse stutters and lags a lot at certain points. At this time, the mouse failed, I had to swipe the mouse over the pad three to four times to reach the requested marker in the game, and then it crashed.\n\nIt's a very nice story and I enjoy the enviroment a lot, but it's a ♥♥♥♥ing crash fest. Now I remember why I uninstalled the game in June 2014 (which was my last save, that I had to come back to, since the game crashed...). Do not buy the game, it's not stable.

reviewText: Well, this game is an engaging investigation so I gladly recommend it even if I encountered a couple of annoying bugs. Twice I just couldn't pick up the objects needed to complete a puzzle or an investigation (even if they were highlighted by pressing the space key) so -at the end of my rope- I have been forced to use downloaded saved games to override those points. These bugs seem to be related somehow to widescreen video resolutions so be aware of that before buying (or just grab saved games from the internet and enjoy the game).

reviewText:
I don't usually write reviews, but I loved this game. It's as close to the ripper murders of 1888 as you will find. The puzzles were a tough challange, but the game was fun. The artwork was outstanding as well as the voice acting and music. I had one problem with my resolution, which through my own investigation was solved. When I got to the second murder scene, I could not click on all of the evidence hot buttons, and could find no answers from the internet discussions and no reply from Frogwares, the developer. If  no resolution is found, you can't proceed. If this happens to you, do the following:
Go to your steam games folder under Common/sherlock holmes vs. jack the ripper/Game folder. Scroll down in the Game folder untill you see Render/fixed_aspect_ratio = false    Change the false to true, and save. You should now be able to enjoy the game after restarting. Here is the info again:
Steam Library
Common
sherlock holmes vs. jack the ripper
Game   - open with notepad and scroll down to
[Render]
fixed_aspect_ratio = false            change false to true         and then save. You are good to go. Cheers!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Overall a good game, fun and decently challenging without becoming frustrating.

+ Some puzzles (deduction, analysing the scene) are very funny
+ Good difficulty, never frustrating (except the yellow ellipse in the puzzle of deducting Jack comfort zone" cause the map on widescreen create some problem for Sherlock to accept your work. Luckily there is a image of how do it to be accepted in the community discussions here on steam)

- Some puzzles are kinda silly to even exist
- Graphics and voice acting are "meh"

A good game
date: worth the time to play it but low replay value. You could probably prefer to buy it when on discount."

reviewText: I've played Nemesis, Awakened, Silver Earring (although never finished that one...), even the Mummy and the Persian Carpet. Sherlock Holmes versus Jack the Ripper is most definitely the best one out of all of them. The developers learned a lot along the way and it shows. Thumbs up!

reviewText: This game was amazing to play! There are some good facts, as well as lots of fiction. It took me 8 hours to complete the game, and I did have to use a walkthrough for some puzzle solutions! I believe some of the gore may have been removed from this release, but generally this game takes you through the mind of derranged serial killer, and doesn't hold back on the details!
